elements.content: To study the synthetic strategy from cages to extended frameworks is very important to elucidate and mimic cage-based self-assembly behavior in zeolites and other open frameworks. Here, two dodecahedral cages are rationally designed by using tridentate boron imidazolate ligands to link tetrahedral or square metal centers. The self-assembly of metal boron imidazolate cages is successfully realized. The cage-based materials display good properties on gas adsorption and reducing noble metals. This work may help us to understand the formation mechanism of extended metal–organic frameworks.
elements.clean_text: To study the synthetic strategy from cages to extended frameworks is very important to elucidate and mimic cage-based self-assembly behavior in zeolites and other open frameworks. Here, two dodecahedral cages are rationally designed by using tridentate boron imidazolate ligands to link tetrahedral or square metal centers. The self-assembly of metal boron imidazolate cages is successfully realized. The cage-based materials display good properties on gas adsorption and reducing noble metals. This work may help us to understand the formation mechanism of extended metal-organic frameworks.

elements.content: Presented here is a dodecahedral boron imidazolate cage, which is rationally designed and further considered to create boron imidazolate frameworks by adding further connectivity from the metal approach.
elements.clean_text: Presented here is a dodecahedral boron imidazolate cage, which is rationally designed and further considered to create boron imidazolate frameworks by adding further connectivity from the metal approach.

elements.content: Recently, coordination cages are of great interest due to their fascinating structures and promising applications in drug delivery, recognition, and catalysis. A lot of coordination cages with different geometries (e.g., tetrahedron, cube, and rhombic dodecahedron) have been reported. Moreover, cages are often considered as basic building units for the construction of extended frameworks. Typically, in the zeolite family, the β-cage is the well-known secondary building unit in many zeolite structures, such as SOD, RHO, LTA, etc. To elucidate and mimic such cage-based self-assembly behavior in zeolites and other open frameworks, it is significant to study the synthetic strategy from cages to extended frameworks. Especially, the ligand functional cages are rarely reported.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, coordination cages are of great interest due to their fascinating structures and promising applications in drug delivery, recognition, and catalysis. A lot of coordination cages with different geometries (e.g., tetrahedron, cube, and rhombic dodecahedron) have been reported. Moreover, cages are often considered as basic building units for the construction of extended frameworks. Typically, in the zeolite family, the β-cage is the well-known secondary building unit in many zeolite structures, such as SOD, RHO, LTA, etc. To elucidate and mimic such cage-based self-assembly behavior in zeolites and other open frameworks, it is significant to study the synthetic strategy from cages to extended frameworks. Especially, the ligand functional cages are rarely reported.

elements.content: Our previous studies have proved that some tridentate or tetradentate boron imidazolate ligands are more likely to link tetrahedral metal centers such as Cu+ and Zn2+ into extended boron imidazolate frameworks (BIFs) with several zeotype topologies. However, in most cases, BIFs with cage-substructures are difficult to obtain as anticipated. Therefore, the controllable assembly of polyhedral coordination cages into three-dimensional frameworks may have advantage to understand the formation mechanism.
elements.clean_text: Our previous studies have proved that some tridentate or tetradentate boron imidazolate ligands are more likely to link tetrahedral metal centers such as Cu+ and Zn2+ into extended boron imidazolate frameworks (BIFs) with several zeotype topologies. However, in most cases, BIFs with cage-substructures are difficult to obtain as anticipated. Therefore, the controllable assembly of polyhedral coordination cages into three-dimensional frameworks may have advantage to understand the formation mechanism.

elements.content: In this work, we present the synthetic design from boron imidazolate cages to frameworks. Although a great deal of construction methods of cages have been documented, rhombic dodecahedral cages based on the boron imidazolate ligands and square metal centers are rarely reported. A feasible synthesis method for the formation of this type of boron imidazolate cages involves divalent metal centers with square coordination geometry. For a typical rhombic dodecahedral cage (M6L8), the square Cu­(II) centers and the tridentate boron imidazolate ligands are considered. To further investigate the self-assembly of cages into a framework, a strategy is employed, which is to use an auxiliary ligand like halogen ions to link metal centers.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we present the synthetic design from boron imidazolate cages to frameworks. Although a great deal of construction methods of cages have been documented, rhombic dodecahedral cages based on the boron imidazolate ligands and square metal centers are rarely reported. A feasible synthesis method for the formation of this type of boron imidazolate cages involves divalent metal centers with square coordination geometry. For a typical rhombic dodecahedral cage (M6L8), the square Cu(II) centers and the tridentate boron imidazolate ligands are considered. To further investigate the self-assembly of cages into a framework, a strategy is employed, which is to use an auxiliary ligand like halogen ions to link metal centers.

elements.content: According to above construction principles, two cage-based boron imidazolate compounds (BIF-29/30) and a boron imidazolate framework (BIF-33) were successfully synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The phase purity of these compounds was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (Figures S1–S5, ). The classical cage mode (M6L8) is presented in these compounds (Schemes and ). Here, the substituted group of imidazole and anions play a crucial role in the formation of such cages and cage-based frameworks. The details are discussed below.
elements.clean_text: According to above construction principles, two cage-based boron imidazolate compounds (BIF-29/30) and a boron imidazolate framework (BIF-33) were successfully synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The phase purity of these compounds was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (Figures S1-S5, ). The classical cage mode (M6L8) is presented in these compounds (Schemes  and ). Here, the substituted group of imidazole and anions play a crucial role in the formation of such cages and cage-based frameworks. The details are discussed below.

elements.content: All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. The Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were carried out on a MiniFlex-II diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 1.0°. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under an air atmosphere. Boron imidazolate complexes were synthesized according to the literature procedure. Gas sorption isotherms of BIF-33 were measured using an ASAP2020 gas adsorption instrument up to 1 atm of gas pressure. The highly pure N2 (99.999%) and CO2 (99.999%) were used in the sorption experiments. Before the measurement, the freshly prepared sample of BIF-33 was exchanged with methanol for 3 days and 3 times. The sample was activated under vacuum at 80 °C for 10 h. The morphologies of Ag@BIF-33 were studied by using a JEOL-2010 transmission electron microscope (TEM) working at 200 kV. The samples were prepared by placing a drop of product in ethanol onto a continuous carbon-coated copper TEM grid. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD system with a base pressure of 10–9 Torr.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instrumentation

All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. The Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were carried out on a MiniFlex-II diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 1.0°. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under an air atmosphere. Boron imidazolate complexes were synthesized according to the literature procedure. Gas sorption isotherms of BIF-33 were measured using an ASAP2020 gas adsorption instrument up to 1 atm of gas pressure. The highly pure N2 (99.999%) and CO2 (99.999%) were used in the sorption experiments. Before the measurement, the freshly prepared sample of BIF-33 was exchanged with methanol for 3 days and 3 times. The sample was activated under vacuum at 80 °C for 10 h. The morphologies of Ag@BIF-33 were studied by using a JEOL-2010 transmission electron microscope (TEM) working at 200 kV. The samples were prepared by placing a drop of product in ethanol onto a continuous carbon-coated copper TEM grid. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD system with a base pressure of 10-9 Torr.

elements.content: KBH­(im)3 (0.058 g), 1,2,3-triazole (0.03 g), and Cu­(NO3)2 (0.124 g) were mixed in DMA (2.5 mL)/methanol (2 mL) solution in a vial and stirred for half an hour. The sample was heated at 80 °C for 7 days, followed by cooling to room temperature. The blue crystals were obtained (Yield: 25%).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of BIF-29 

KBH(im)3 (0.058 g), 1,2,3-triazole (0.03 g), and Cu(NO3)2 (0.124 g) were mixed in DMA (2.5 mL)/methanol (2 mL) solution in a vial and stirred for half an hour. The sample was heated at 80 °C for 7 days, followed by cooling to room temperature. The blue crystals were obtained (Yield: 25%).

elements.content: KBH­(dm-bim)3 (0.0359 g), tetraphenylphosphonium bromide (0.0181 g), and Cu2O (0.0095 g) in a mixed 1,3-dimethyl-propyleneurea (DMPU, 5.2660 g)/acetonitrile (1.5 mL) solution were placed in a 20 mL vial. The sample was heated at 80 °C for 7 days, and then cooled to room temperature. After the resultant was washed with ethanol and distilled water, the blue crystals were obtained (Yield: 30%).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of BIF-30 

KBH(dm-bim)3 (0.0359 g), tetraphenylphosphonium bromide (0.0181 g), and Cu2O (0.0095 g) in a mixed 1,3-dimethyl-propyleneurea (DMPU, 5.2660 g)/acetonitrile (1.5 mL) solution were placed in a 20 mL vial. The sample was heated at 80 °C for 7 days, and then cooled to room temperature. After the resultant was washed with ethanol and distilled water, the blue crystals were obtained (Yield: 30%).

elements.content: KBH­(im)3 (0.061 g), CuI (0.06 g), DMF (4 mL), and ethanol (1 mL) were mixed in a 20 mL vial and stirred for half an hour. The vial was then sealed and heated at 80 °C for 7 days, followed by cooling to room temperature. The blue crystals were obtained (Yield: 37%).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of BIF-33 

KBH(im)3 (0.061 g), CuI (0.06 g), DMF (4 mL), and ethanol (1 mL) were mixed in a 20 mL vial and stirred for half an hour. The vial was then sealed and heated at 80 °C for 7 days, followed by cooling to room temperature. The blue crystals were obtained (Yield: 37%).

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on a CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXTL-97 program package. The SQUEEZE option of PLATON was used to eliminate the contribution of disordered guest molecules to the reflection intensities. Crystallographic data of the compounds are given in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Diffraction Analysis

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on a CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXTL-97 program package. The SQUEEZE option of PLATON was used to eliminate the contribution of disordered guest molecules to the reflection intensities. Crystallographic data of the compounds are given in Table .

elements.content:
Summary of Crystal Data and Refinement Results BIF-29 BIF-30 BIF-33 chemical formula C72H72B8Cu6N48 C216H216B8BrCu6N48O10 C72H72B8Cu6I3N48 formula mass 2077.50 4192.00 2458.20 crystal system cubic tetragonal hexagonal a/Å 22.0954(6) 18.9015(2) 20.1157(5) b/Å 22.0954(6) 18.9015(2) 20.1157(5) c/Å 22.0954(6) 31.6878(6) 59.6452(18) α/deg 90.00 90.00 90.00 β/deg 90.00 90.00 90.00 γ/deg 90.00 90.00 120.00 unit cell volume/Å3 10787.1(5) 11321.0(3) 20901.4(10) temperature/K 173(2) 293(2) 173(2) space group Fm3̅ P4/n R3C no. of formula units per unit cell, Z 4 2 6 no. of reflections measured 2333 24727 13363 no. of independent reflections 867 11258 6000 R int 0.0567 0.0435 0.0818 final R 1 values (I > 2σ(I)) 0.1083 0.1245 0.0659 final wR(F 2) values (I > 2σ(I)) 0.3729 0.3381 0.1516 goodness of fit on F 2 0.990 0.987 0.944

R 1 = ∑(|F o| – |F c|)/∑|F o|; wR 2 = [∑w(F o 2 – F c 2)/∑w(F o 2)2]1/2.

Here, BH­(dm-bim)3 – ligands were used to synthesize BIF-30 (Cu6[BH­(dm-bim)3]8­Br­(H2O)4­(OH)3), and the BH­(im)3 – (im = imidazolate) ligands were used to fabricate BIF-29 (Cu6[BH­(im)3]8­(H2O)6­(NO3)4) and BIF-33 (Cu6[BH­(im)3]8I4), respectively. BIF-29 and BIF-30 crystallized in Fm3̅ and P4/n space groups, respectively. Each dodecahedral cage in BIF-29 or BIF-30 is made up of six Cu­(II) ions and eight boron imidazolate ligands (Figure a,b), where the Cu­(II) and boron imidazolate building blocks represent square and triangular vertices, respectively. Although similar M6L8 cages have been rationally built by other tritopic organic linkers and even tetradentate boron imidazolate ligands with Pd­(II) centers, this is the first time to realize this cage by combing tridentate boron imidazolate ligands and much cheap Cu­(II) centers. In BIF-30, the square plane of each Cu2+ center is formed by four N atoms from four BH­(dm-bim)3 – ligands. The Cu···Cu distance between two opposite square pyramidal Cu2+ centers is 11.339 Å, and the diagonal distance between two Cu2+ centers is 14.388 Å. The free void in the cage is indicated by the yellow sphere with a diameter of ca. 9 Å; the volume of the van der Waals sphere is ca. 574 Å3.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Here, BH(dm-bim)3 - ligands were used to synthesize BIF-30 (Cu6[BH(dm-bim)3]8Br(H2O)4(OH)3), and the BH(im)3 - (im = imidazolate) ligands were used to fabricate BIF-29 (Cu6[BH(im)3]8(H2O)6(NO3)4) and BIF-33 (Cu6[BH(im)3]8I4), respectively. BIF-29 and BIF-30 crystallized in Fm3̅ and P4/n space groups, respectively. Each dodecahedral cage in BIF-29 or BIF-30 is made up of six Cu(II) ions and eight boron imidazolate ligands (Figure a,b), where the Cu(II) and boron imidazolate building blocks represent square and triangular vertices, respectively. Although similar M6L8 cages have been rationally built by other tritopic organic linkers and even tetradentate boron imidazolate ligands with Pd(II) centers, this is the first time to realize this cage by combing tridentate boron imidazolate ligands and much cheap Cu(II) centers. In BIF-30, the square plane of each Cu2+ center is formed by four N atoms from four BH(dm-bim)3 - ligands. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance between two opposite square pyramidal Cu2+ centers is 11.339 Å, and the diagonal distance between two Cu2+ centers is 14.388 Å. The free void in the cage is indicated by the yellow sphere with a diameter of ca. 9 Å; the volume of the van der Waals sphere is ca. 574 Å3.

elements.content: (a) The dodecahedral cage in BIF-29. (b) The dodecahedral cage in BIF-30. (c) The packing of cages in BIF-29. (d) The packing of cages in BIF-30. The big yellow ball represents the cavity in the cage. Color codes: Cu, pale blue; B, purple; O, red; C, gray; N, blue. H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The dodecahedral cage in BIF-29. (b) The dodecahedral cage in BIF-30. (c) The packing of cages in BIF-29. (d) The packing of cages in BIF-30. The big yellow ball represents the cavity in the cage. Color codes: Cu, pale blue; B, purple; O, red; C, gray; N, blue. H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: It is interesting to note that BIF-30 and BIF-29 have different solubility in benzene, which is ascribed to their surface structural features. Both BIF-30 and BIF-29 are sparingly soluble in some solutions, such as DMF, DMSO, and H2O. However, BIF-30 is easily soluble in benzene, but BIF-29 cannot be dissolved by benzene. It is obvious that the cage with BH­(dm-bim)3 – ligands in BIF-30 has hydrophobic character on the outside surface. Moreover, four coordinated water molecules are located inside the cage of BIF-30, which leads to a hydrophilic environment showing a hydrophilic environment. In contrast to BIF-30, the outside surface of the cage in BIF-29 is occupied by six coordinated water molecules, showing a hydrophilic environment. Such different surface characters of the cages lead to different packing modes of the cages (Figure c,d).
elements.clean_text: It is interesting to note that BIF-30 and BIF-29 have different solubility in benzene, which is ascribed to their surface structural features. Both BIF-30 and BIF-29 are sparingly soluble in some solutions, such as DMF, DMSO, and H2O. However, BIF-30 is easily soluble in benzene, but BIF-29 cannot be dissolved by benzene. It is obvious that the cage with BH(dm-bim)3 - ligands in BIF-30 has hydrophobic character on the outside surface. Moreover, four coordinated water molecules are located inside the cage of BIF-30, which leads to a hydrophilic environment showing a hydrophilic environment. In contrast to BIF-30, the outside surface of the cage in BIF-29 is occupied by six coordinated water molecules, showing a hydrophilic environment. Such different surface characters of the cages lead to different packing modes of the cages (Figure c,d).

elements.content: Inspired by fascinating discrete structures of cages, we tend to think that a strategy may be used to link the cages into frameworks. The approach is to import auxiliary linkers to link the metal centers in the cage. Typically, in the dodecahedral cage, the Cu center has unsaturated coordination sites, because the terminated ligands are water molecules. Thus, a bridging linker is possible to substitute these unsaturated coordination sites and connect two cages together. Such a synthetic strategy is successfully realized by a BIF-33 (Cu6[BH­(im)3]8I4) framework that has dodecahedral cages linked by the μ2-I– anions. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that BIF-33 crystallized in the hexgonal space group R3c. It exhibits a three-dimensional (3D) framework with a CuBH­(im)3 cage substructure. Compared with the simple cage structure in BIF-30, all Cu centers in BIF-33 are bridged by the μ2-I– anions (Figure a). Since each dodecahedral cage has six Cu centers, each dodecahedral cage connects to six adjacent cages through six μ2-I– anions (Figure b). Finally, such connectivity generates a 3D open framework with a 1D channel along the c axis. PLATON calculations showed that the total empty volume of the cationic framework is 44.3%. In addition, the structure of BIF-33 can be topologically represented as a 6-connected pcu net by considering each dodecahedral cage as a 6-connected node (Figure S6, ).
elements.clean_text: Inspired by fascinating discrete structures of cages, we tend to think that a strategy may be used to link the cages into frameworks. The approach is to import auxiliary linkers to link the metal centers in the cage. Typically, in the dodecahedral cage, the Cu center has unsaturated coordination sites, because the terminated ligands are water molecules. Thus, a bridging linker is possible to substitute these unsaturated coordination sites and connect two cages together. Such a synthetic strategy is successfully realized by a BIF-33 (Cu6[BH(im)3]8I4) framework that has dodecahedral cages linked by the μ2-I- anions. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that BIF-33 crystallized in the hexgonal space group R3c. It exhibits a three-dimensional (3D) framework with a CuBH(im)3 cage substructure. Compared with the simple cage structure in BIF-30, all Cu centers in BIF-33 are bridged by the μ2-I- anions (Figure a). Since each dodecahedral cage has six Cu centers, each dodecahedral cage connects to six adjacent cages through six μ2-I- anions (Figure b). Finally, such connectivity generates a 3D open framework with a 1D channel along the c axis. PLATON calculations showed that the total empty volume of the cationic framework is 44.3%. In addition, the structure of BIF-33 can be topologically represented as a 6-connected pcu net by considering each dodecahedral cage as a 6-connected node (Figure S6, ).

elements.content: (a) The dodecahedral cage with μ2-I– anions in BIF-33. (b) The connectivity between the dodecahedral cages in BIF-33. The big yellow ball represents the cavity in the cage. Color codes: Cu, pale blue; B, purple; O, red; C, gray; N, blue. H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) The dodecahedral cage with μ2-I- anions in BIF-33. (b) The connectivity between the dodecahedral cages in BIF-33. The big yellow ball represents the cavity in the cage. Color codes: Cu, pale blue; B, purple; O, red; C, gray; N, blue. H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The permanent porosity of BIF-33 was confirmed by N2 adsorption measurements at 77 K. The N2 uptake value is 165 cm3/g at 77 K (Figure S7, ), which is significantly higher than that of MOP-101. The calculated Langmuir and BET surface areas are 420 and 350 m2/g, respectively. The CO2 uptake values are 45 cm3/g at 273 K and 20 cm3/g at 298 K (Figure S8, ), which are comparable to some highly porous ZIF-100.
elements.clean_text: The permanent porosity of BIF-33 was confirmed by N2 adsorption measurements at 77 K. The N2 uptake value is 165 cm3/g at 77 K (Figure S7, ), which is significantly higher than that of MOP-101. The calculated Langmuir and BET surface areas are 420 and 350 m2/g, respectively. The CO2 uptake values are 45 cm3/g at 273 K and 20 cm3/g at 298 K (Figure S8, ), which are comparable to some highly porous ZIF-100.

elements.content: Inspired by our previous studies, the presence of potentially active B–H bonds from tridentate boron imidazolate ligands could serve as the reducing agent and contribute to the direct formation of metal nanoparticles (NPs) in crystals. We have tried to extend this method to control the synthesis of Ag-NPs in the 0D compounds. Fortunately, a one-pot process was realized for the preparation of the Ag@BIF-30 sample. Fresh BIF-30 crystals (80 mg) were immersed in the methanol solution of AgNO3 (5 mmol/L, 10 mL) for 12 h at room temperature. The color of Ag@BIF-30 crystals changed from blue to gray. Here, Ag+ serves as the oxidation agent, and BIF-30 was the reducing agent. The field-emission (FE) TEM image of the resulting Ag@BIF-30 sample indicated the formation of Ag NPs in the crystals (Figure a,b). The average size of NPs is about 20 nm. To obtain further information on the composition of Ag@BIF-30, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) were used to analyze the sample (Figures S9 and S10, ). XPS spectra of the Ag@BIF-30 shows the binding energies of Ag(0) (368 and 374 eV, 3d5/2 and 3d3/2, respectively). No obvious peak of Ag+ is observed, which indicates that the Ag NPs are stable in the encapsulation procedure. The PXRD patterns further prove that the host framework is retained after loading Ag-NPs. Moreover, the lattice fringe spacing of the Ag-NPs was measured to be 0.23 nm (Figure c), which matches the d value for Ag(111). We can conclude that the BIF-30 crystals have directly produced Ag-NPs in their phase without any external reducing agent.
elements.clean_text: Inspired by our previous studies, the presence of potentially active B-H bonds from tridentate boron imidazolate ligands could serve as the reducing agent and contribute to the direct formation of metal nanoparticles (NPs) in crystals. We have tried to extend this method to control the synthesis of Ag-NPs in the 0D compounds. Fortunately, a one-pot process was realized for the preparation of the Ag@BIF-30 sample. Fresh BIF-30 crystals (80 mg) were immersed in the methanol solution of AgNO3 (5 mmol/L, 10 mL) for 12 h at room temperature. The color of Ag@BIF-30 crystals changed from blue to gray. Here, Ag+ serves as the oxidation agent, and BIF-30 was the reducing agent. The field-emission (FE) TEM image of the resulting Ag@BIF-30 sample indicated the formation of Ag NPs in the crystals (Figure a,b). The average size of NPs is about 20 nm. To obtain further information on the composition of Ag@BIF-30, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) were used to analyze the sample (Figures S9 and S10, ). XPS spectra of the Ag@BIF-30 shows the binding energies of Ag(0) (368 and 374 eV, 3d5/2 and 3d3/2, respectively). No obvious peak of Ag+ is observed, which indicates that the Ag NPs are stable in the encapsulation procedure. The PXRD patterns further prove that the host framework is retained after loading Ag-NPs. Moreover, the lattice fringe spacing of the Ag-NPs was measured to be 0.23 nm (Figure c), which matches the d value for Ag(111). We can conclude that the BIF-30 crystals have directly produced Ag-NPs in their phase without any external reducing agent.

elements.content: (a) TEM image of Ag@BIF-30. (b) TEM image of Ag@BIF-30 after catalytic reaction. (c) HRTEM image of Ag@BIF-30. (d) UV–vis spectra showing gradual reduction of 4-NP over Ag@BIF-30.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) TEM image of Ag@BIF-30. (b) TEM image of Ag@BIF-30 after catalytic reaction. (c) HRTEM image of Ag@BIF-30. (d) UV-vis spectra showing gradual reduction of 4-NP over Ag@BIF-30.

elements.content: The reduction of 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) by NaBH4 was chosen as a model reaction for studying the catalytic performance of Ag@BIF-30. The reaction was monitored by UV–vis absorption spectroscopy of the reaction mixture after the addition of the catalyst Ag@BIF-30 (Figure d). The satisfied test results indicated that it is of high catalytic behaviors. In addition, TEM measurements indicate that the sizes of the Ag-NPs are still unchanged after three runs, which suggests that Ag@BIF-30 can act as an excellent catalysis to reduce 4-nitrophenol (Figures S11 and S12, ).
elements.clean_text: The reduction of 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) by NaBH4 was chosen as a model reaction for studying the catalytic performance of Ag@BIF-30. The reaction was monitored by UV-vis absorption spectroscopy of the reaction mixture after the addition of the catalyst Ag@BIF-30 (Figure d). The satisfied test results indicated that it is of high catalytic behaviors. In addition, TEM measurements indicate that the sizes of the Ag-NPs are still unchanged after three runs, which suggests that Ag@BIF-30 can act as an excellent catalysis to reduce 4-nitrophenol (Figures S11 and S12, ).

elements.content: In summary, three compounds with dodecahedral cages have been rationally designed by using tridentate boron imidazolate ligands to link square metal centers. The substituted group of imidazole may tune the packing structure of the cages. Moreover, the metal center in the cage can be considered to add further connectivity, which realizes the bottom-up structural transformation from boron imidazolate cages to boron imidazolate frameworks. This work provided the first evidence on understanding the building mechanism of cage-based structures, such as zeolites and other zeolitic metal–organic frameworks. Furthermore, BIF-33 can directly load Ag-NPs without the presence of other reducing agents, and Ag@BIF-30 can act as a catalyst to reduce 4-nitrophenol. These results demonstrated the potential application of cage-based BIF materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, three compounds with dodecahedral cages have been rationally designed by using tridentate boron imidazolate ligands to link square metal centers. The substituted group of imidazole may tune the packing structure of the cages. Moreover, the metal center in the cage can be considered to add further connectivity, which realizes the bottom-up structural transformation from boron imidazolate cages to boron imidazolate frameworks. This work provided the first evidence on understanding the building mechanism of cage-based structures, such as zeolites and other zeolitic metal-organic frameworks. Furthermore, BIF-33 can directly load Ag-NPs without the presence of other reducing agents, and Ag@BIF-30 can act as a catalyst to reduce 4-nitrophenol. These results demonstrated the potential application of cage-based BIF materials.

cln_elements.content:
KBH­(im)3 (0.058 g), 1,2,3-triazole (0.03 g), and Cu­(NO3)2 (0.124 g) were mixed in DMA (2.5 mL)/methanol (2 mL) solution in a vial and stirred for half an hour. The sample was heated at 80 °C for 7 days, followed by cooling to room temperature. The blue crystals were obtained (Yield: 25%).

Synthesis of <bold>BIF-30</bold>

KBH­(dm-bim)3 (0.0359 g), tetraphenylphosphonium bromide (0.0181 g), and Cu2O (0.0095 g) in a mixed 1,3-dimethyl-propyleneurea (DMPU, 5.2660 g)/acetonitrile (1.5 mL) solution were placed in a 20 mL vial. The sample was heated at 80 °C for 7 days, and then cooled to room temperature. After the resultant was washed with ethanol and distilled water, the blue crystals were obtained (Yield: 30%).

Synthesis of <bold>BIF-33</bold>

KBH­(im)3 (0.061 g), CuI (0.06 g), DMF (4 mL), and ethanol (1 mL) were mixed in a 20 mL vial and stirred for half an hour. The vial was then sealed and heated at 80 °C for 7 days, followed by cooling to room temperature. The blue crystals were obtained (Yield: 37%).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of BIF-29 

KBH(im)3 (0.058 g), 1,2,3-triazole (0.03 g), and Cu(NO3)2 (0.124 g) were mixed in DMA (2.5 mL)/methanol (2 mL) solution in a vial and stirred for half an hour. The sample was heated at 80 °C for 7 days, followed by cooling to room temperature. The blue crystals were obtained (Yield: 25%).

Synthesis of BIF-30 

KBH(dm-bim)3 (0.0359 g), tetraphenylphosphonium bromide (0.0181 g), and Cu2O (0.0095 g) in a mixed 1,3-dimethyl-propyleneurea (DMPU, 5.2660 g)/acetonitrile (1.5 mL) solution were placed in a 20 mL vial. The sample was heated at 80 °C for 7 days, and then cooled to room temperature. After the resultant was washed with ethanol and distilled water, the blue crystals were obtained (Yield: 30%).

Synthesis of BIF-33 

KBH(im)3 (0.061 g), CuI (0.06 g), DMF (4 mL), and ethanol (1 mL) were mixed in a 20 mL vial and stirred for half an hour. The vial was then sealed and heated at 80 °C for 7 days, followed by cooling to room temperature. The blue crystals were obtained (Yield: 37%).

cln_elements.content: The permanent porosity of BIF-33 was confirmed by N2 adsorption measurements at 77 K. The N2 uptake value is 165 cm3/g at 77 K (Figure S7, ), which is significantly higher than that of MOP-101. The calculated Langmuir and BET surface areas are 420 and 350 m2/g, respectively. The CO2 uptake values are 45 cm3/g at 273 K and 20 cm3/g at 298 K (Figure S8, ), which are comparable to some highly porous ZIF-100.
cln_elements.clean_text: The permanent porosity of BIF-33 was confirmed by N2 adsorption measurements at 77 K. The N2 uptake value is 165 cm3/g at 77 K (Figure S7, ), which is significantly higher than that of MOP-101. The calculated Langmuir and BET surface areas are 420 and 350 m2/g, respectively. The CO2 uptake values are 45 cm3/g at 273 K and 20 cm3/g at 298 K (Figure S8, ), which are comparable to some highly porous ZIF-100.
